title: 112_hr1638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dollar Bill Act of 2011". Congress acknowledges that the Federal Reserve System has been delegated the power to regulate the value of US and foreign currency, but notes that the value of the US dollar has significantly decreased and become unstable. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not provided a stable value for the US dollar. The unstable US dollar has negative effects on the economy, including increasing the cost of capital, reducing real earnings for workers, and diminishing the value of financial assets and retirement accounts. An unstable dollar negatively impacts the US economy, leading to increased costs, reduced earnings, and diminished asset values. It also affects the country's global standing and creates anxiety and uncertainty in financial markets and among the public. SEC. 3. DIRECTIVES TO THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is directed to make the value of the U.S. dollar equal to the price of gold on the COMEX exchange and maintain it at that level. They are also instructed to use banking powers to ensure stable financial markets during and after the transition. Effective January 1, 2011, entities can expense 100 percent of capital investment for tax purposes in the year of investment. SEC. 5. The Congressional Budget Office will calculate the impact on Federal revenues of tax changes in this Act on a present value basis, similar to Social Security Trustees' calculations. It considers first-year expensing of capital investment and higher returns on business investments. SEC. 6. Conflict of laws provision. SEC. 6. CONFLICT OF LAWS PROVISION. In case of conflict with the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act of 1978, this Act supersedes. SEC. 7. REMOVAL OF FEDERAL RESERVE BANK AUTHORITY TO PAY EARNINGS ON RESERVES. SEC. 7. REMOVAL OF FEDERAL RESERVE BANK AUTHORITY TO PAY EARNINGS ON RESERVES. Amendment to the Federal Reserve Act prohibits Federal Reserve banks from paying earnings on reserves.
